items.title: UK government insiders say AI datacenters may be a pricey white elephant
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Economy-boosting bit barn? Not in my back yard, some locals expected to say

The British government is pressing ahead with "AI Growth Zones" amid fears the rush to build datacenters to power AI could backfire and leave the countryside littered with expensive high-tech "white elephants."…

items.title: AI summaries turn real news into nonsense, BBC finds
items.author: Richard Currie
items.summary:
Research after Apple Intelligence fiasco shows bots still regularly make stuff up

Still smarting from Apple Intelligence butchering a headline, the BBC has published research into how accurately AI assistants summarize news – and the results don't make for happy reading.…

items.title: Murena boss says customers about to wake up from its cloud storage nightmare
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Four months since cloud drive kicked the bucket, but resolution comes today... hopefully

Interview  How long can a cloud storage outage continue before customers finally give up the ghost? Management at Murena – /e/OS maker – must have wrestled with this at night, though they hope a fix is around the corner.…

items.title: Oxford researchers pull off quantum first with distributed gate teleportation
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Einstein’s spooky action at a distance just got an upgrade

Oxford University researchers have taken a significant step toward large-scale distributed quantum computing by demonstrating the first successful quantum teleportation of a controlled quantum gate between two modules.…

items.title: Ignorance really is bliss when you’re drowning in information
items.author: Mark Pesce
items.summary:
If only the joy of missing out was easier to achieve

Column  I've never seriously accepted the maxim "ignorance is bliss". Now I'm less sure.…

items.title: After Copilot trial, government staff rated Microsoft's AI less useful than expected
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Not all bad news for Redmond as Australian agency also found strong ROI and some unexpected upsides

Australia’s Department of the Treasury has found that Microsoft’s Copilot can easily deliver return on investment, but staff exposed to the AI assistant came away from the experience less confident it will help them at work.…

items.title: February's Patch Tuesday sees Microsoft offer just 63 fixes
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
Don't relax just yet: Redmond has made some certificate-handling changes that could trip unprepared admins

Patch Tuesday  Microsoft’s February patch collection is mercifully smaller than January’s mega-dump. But don't get too relaxed – some deserve close attention, and other vendors have stepped in with plenty more fixes.…

items.title: A win at last: Big-time blow to AI world in training data copyright scrap
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
You gotta fight ... for your Reuters ... to party

Thomson Reuters has won a partial summary judgment in a copyright case against shuttered AI firm Ross Intelligence, a decision that disallows fair use as a defense for training models on proprietary data without permission.…

items.title: Microsoft wants to quit working on Army VR goggles, hand contract to Anduril
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Will the Pentagon get Luckey with a new IVAS vendor?

Microsoft plans to quit developing augmented-reality headsets for the US Army and have Oculus founder Palmer Luckey's Anduril Industries take over the gig.…

items.title: Probe finds US Coast Guard has left maritime cybersecurity adrift
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
Numerous systemic vulnerabilities could scuttle $5.4T industry

Despite the escalating cyber threats targeting America's maritime transportation system, the US Coast Guard still lacks a comprehensive strategy to secure this critical infrastructure - nor does it have reliable access to data on cybersecurity vulnerabilities and past attacks, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) warns.…

items.title: Yup, AMD's Elba and Giglio definitely sound like they work corporate security
items.author: Tobias Mann
items.summary:
Which is why Cisco is adding these Pensando DPUs to more switches

Cisco is cramming into more of its switches Pensando data processing units (DPUs) from AMD, which will be dedicated to handling security, storage, and other tasks.…

items.title: 'Key kernel maintainers' still back Rust in the Linux kernel, despite the doubters
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
Rustaceans could just wait for unwelcoming C coders to slowly SIGQUIT...

The Rust for Linux project is alive and well, despite suggestions to the contrary, even if not every Linux kernel maintainer is an ally.…

items.title: Triplestrength hits victims with triple trouble: Ransomware, cloud hijacks, crypto-mining
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
These crooks have no chill

A previously unknown gang dubbed Triplestrength poses a triple threat to organizations: It infects victims' computers with ransomware, then hijacks their cloud accounts to illegally mine for cryptocurrency.…

items.title: UK, US, Oz blast holes in LockBit's bulletproof hosting provider Zservers
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Huge if true: Brit Foreign Sec says Putin running a 'corrupt mafia state'

One of the bulletproof hosting (BPH) providers used by the LockBit ransomware operation has been hit with sanctions in the US, UK, and Australia (AUKUS), along with six of its key allies.…

items.title: Final cumulative update for Exchange Server 2019 lands at last
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
End of the road in sight for venerable server

Administrators rejoice! The 2025 H1 Cumulative Update (aka CU15) for Exchange Server 2019 has finally arrived, marking the end of an era for the server application.…

items.title: Man who binned 7,500 Bitcoin drive now wants to buy entire landfill to dig it up
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
More than a decade on, waste experts say the odds of finding those coins are next to nil

Denied permission to excavate a landfill in search of his missing Bitcoin, Newport, Wales resident James Howells has a new plan: buy the soon-to-be-capped dumping site outright from the city council.…

items.title: Man who SIM-swapped the SEC's X account pleads guilty
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Said to have asked search engine 'What are some signs that the FBI is after you?'

An Alabama man is pleading guilty after being charged with SIM swapping the Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) X account in January last year.…

items.title: Oracle makes Fusion apps available on EU Sovereign Cloud
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
GDPR-compliant service pitched for public sector orgs who can't pipe data offsite

Oracle is launching a Fusion Cloud Applications Suite (FCAS) on its Oracle EU Sovereign Cloud in a move designed to offer app users greater assurance in compliance with the region's data law.…

items.title: I'm a security expert, and I almost fell for a North Korea-style deepfake job applicant …Twice
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
Remote position, webcam not working, then glitchy AI face ... Red alert!

Twice, over the past two months, Dawid Moczadło has interviewed purported job seekers only to discover that these "software developers" were scammers using AI-based tools — likely to get hired at a security company also using artificial intelligence, and then steal source code or other sensitive IP.…

items.title: Google confirms Gulf of Mexico renamed to appease Trump – but only in the US
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
So now everyone's happy

Updated  Google has changed the name of the Gulf of Mexico on Google Maps to comply with a Donald Trump whim – but only for American users.…

items.title: Microsoft open sources PostgreSQL extensions to muscle in on NoSQL
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
But will it set a real standard for MongoDB alternatives?

Analysis  When Microsoft rolled out an open source extension stack for PostgreSQL to handle document-style data, it wasn't just taking aim at MongoDB – the dominant NoSQL player – but also blurring the lines between relational and non-relational databases, according to one expert.…

items.title: DeepMind working on distributed training of large AI models
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Alternate process could be a game changer if they can make it practicable

Is distributed training the future of AI? As the shock of the DeepSeek release fades, its legacy may be an awareness that alternative approaches to model training are worth exploring, and DeepMind researchers say they've come up with a way of making distributed training much more efficient.…

items.title: Already three years late, NHS finance system replacement delayed again
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Project to swap out Oracle E-Business Suite gets another red rating from projects watchdog

The UK's largest NHS management body has postponed the replacement of its aging Oracle finance system again following more than three years of delays.…

items.title: Euro cloud crew says we-won't-sue deal with Microsoft is 'off-track'
items.author: Paul Kunert
items.summary:
Overseas pals urge US tech giant to 'rapidly' work on Azure Local project to make things right – sans licenses

Microsoft is not on track to meet technical commitments that form the basis of a settlement agreement intended to resolve a legal dispute over software licensing with a gaggle of cloud providers in Europe.…

items.title: UK government using AI tools to check up on roadworthy testing centers
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Who tests the testers?

The UK's Department for Science, Innovation and Technology (DSIT) has produced a list showing how the country uses AI technologies to perform tasks ranging from speeding up the planning process to prioritizing the inspection of MOT testing centers.…

items.title: RIP Raymond Bird: Designer of UK's first mass-produced business computer dies aged 101
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
Engineer was behind the HEC series and more

Obit  Raymond Bird, who developed the UK's first mass-produced business computer, the Hollerith Electronic Computer (HEC), has died at the digitally apropos age of 101.…

items.title: Only 4 percent of jobs rely heavily on AI, with peak use in mid-wage roles
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
Mid-salary knowledge jobs in tech, media, and education are changing. Folk in physical jobs have less to sweat about

Workers in just four percent of occupations use AI for three quarters of their tasks, according to research from Anthropic that explores how its Claude model is used.…

items.title: NASA’s radiation tolerant computer lives up to its name after surviving Van Allen belts
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
'RadPC' flew on Firefly’s Ghost Riders in the Sky mission, which has left Earth Orbit and is headed for the Moon

NASA has revealed its experimental Radiation Tolerant Computer has made it through the famously and furiously radiating Van Allen belts in one piece.…

items.title: January earthquake shook $165M off TSMC’s revenue forecast
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Promises production schedule will get back on track

Taiwanese chipmaking champion TSMC has revealed that a January earthquake will cost it millions.…

items.title: Apple warns 'extremely sophisticated attack' may be targeting iThings
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
Cupertino mostly uses bland language when talking security, so this sounds nasty

Apple has warned that some iPhones and iPads may have been targeted by an “extremely sophisticated attack” and has posted patches that hopefully prevent it.…

items.title: Some workers already let AI do the thinking for them, Microsoft researchers find
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Dammit, that was our job here at The Reg. Now if you get a task you don't understand, you may assume AI has the answers

Some knowledge workers risk becoming over-reliant on generative AI and their problem-solving skills may decline as a result, according to a study penned by researchers from Microsoft Research and Carnegie Mellon University.…

items.title: All your 8Base are belong to us: Ransomware crew busted in global sting
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
Dark web site seized, four cuffed in Thailand

updated  An international police operation spanning the US, Europe, and Asia has shuttered the 8Base ransomware crew's dark web presence and resulted in the arrest of four European suspects accused of stealing $16 million from more than 1,000 victims worldwide.…

items.title: Intel loses another exec as datacenter, AI chief named Nokia CEO
items.author: Tobias Mann
items.summary:
Justin Hotard tapped to replace Pekka Lundmark at the Finnish telco

Intel is going to need more than a new CEO after its Datacenter and AI (DCAI) chief on Monday announced he's leaving to run Nokia as its next chief executive.…

items.title: Reclassification is making US tech job losses look worse than they are
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
IT hiring ticks up in January, but unemployment climbs to 5.7%

The latest job numbers from the US Bureau of Labor Statistics make IT hiring look like it's in freefall, but that's not the case at all, says consultancy firm Janco. …

items.title: Meta's plan to erase 5% of workforce starts today
items.author: Paul Kunert
items.summary:
'Intense year' ahead, warned Zuck. Got to spend billions on AI and work to stay out of Trump's bad books

Meta has confirmed to The Register that today marks the start of a mass redundancy process with thousands of workers getting the chop.…

items.title: T-Mobile goes live with beta of satellite phone service for the US
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Free text messages for users of its own and rival networks during test period

T-Mobile US has started a public beta of its Direct-to-Cell service using Starlink satellites, offering just text messages for now, with data and voice calls coming later. Access will be free until July – after which it will cost $15 per month.…

items.title: Boeing warns SLS staff that job cuts could be on the way
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Overdue, over budget and now... perhaps just over?

Boeing has notified staff that hundreds of jobs could be eliminated if the Artemis program is canceled or heavily revised.…

items.title: The biggest microcode attack in our history is underway
items.author: Rupert Goodwins
items.summary:
When your state machines are vulnerable, all bets are off

Opinion  All malicious attacks on digital systems have one common aim: taking control. Mostly, that means getting a CPU somewhere to turn traitor, running code that silently steals or scrambles your data. That code can ride into the system in a whole spectrum of ways, but usually it has to be in memory somewhere at some time, making it amenable to counter-attack.…

items.title: Sri Lanka goes bananas after monkey unplugs nation
items.author: Richard Currie
items.summary:
Simian saboteur or a grid screaming for modernization?

Sri Lanka's electricity grid was brought down nationwide on Sunday after monkey business struck a power station south of the capital of Colombo.…

items.title: US news org still struggling to print papers a week after 'cybersecurity event'
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Publications across 25 states either producing smaller issues or very delayed ones

US newspaper publisher Lee Enterprises is one week into tackling a nondescript "cybersecurity event," saying the related investigation may take "weeks or longer" to complete.…

items.title: CentOS Connect conference announces return of Firefox
items.author: Liam Proven
items.summary:
OKD project also has its own immutable CentOS image, which could be fun

FOSDEM 2025  CentOS Connect, the FOSDEM-adjacent meetup, delivered a few notable updates: Firefox is returning as a native package on CentOS, an immutable Stream variant is being explored, and AlmaLinux is doing things its own way.…

items.title: Legacy systems running UK's collector are taxing – in more ways than one
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Costs for fixing them and keeping them working up by 390%, NAO report reveals

Updated  Costs associated with the remediation of the UK tax collector's legacy systems have risen by up to 390 percent, according to a new report from government auditors.…

items.title: London has 400 GW of grid requests holding up datacenter builds
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
And up to 70% of stalled energy generation projects are unlikely to be approved, claims regulator Ofgem

While the UK government wants to turbocharge datacenter construction, a newly published report says there are already 400 GW worth of outstanding requests for connection to the power grid around London, and regulator Ofgem estimates 60-70 percent of these will never happen.…

items.title: UK armed forces fast-tracking cyber warriors to defend digital front lines
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
High starting salaries promised after public sector infosec pay criticized

The UK's Ministry of Defence (MoD) is fast-tracking cybersecurity specialists in a bid to fortify its protection against increasing attacks.…

items.title: Does this thing run on a 220 V power supply? Oh. That puff of smoke suggests not
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
That's not even the worst part of this story, which features a flood, broken promises, and plenty of panic

Who, Me?  The working week has rolled around again, bringing with it the promise of new achievements – and the chance to mess things up in ways that we cover here in "Who, Me?" The Register's reader-contributed column in which you admit to your failures.…

items.title: Cloudflare hopes to rebuild the Web for the AI age - with itself in the middle
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Also claims it’s found DeepSeek-eque optimizations that reduce AI infrastructure requirements

Cloudflare has declared it’s found optimizations that reduce the amount of hardware needed for inferencing workloads, and is in early talks to re-invent the World Wide Web for the age of AI…

items.title: Judge says US Treasury ‘more vulnerable to hacking’ since Trump let the DOGE out
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Order requires destruction of departmental data accessed by Musky men

Trump administration policies that allowed Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency to access systems and data at the Bureau of the Fiscal Service (BFS) have left the org “more vulnerable to hacking” according to federal Judge Paul A. Engelmayer in New York City.…

items.title: India's banking on the bank.in domain cleaning up its financial services sector
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
With over 2,000 banks in operation, a domain only they can use has potential to make life harder for fraudsters

India’s Reserve Bank last week announced a plan to use adopt dedicated second-level domains – bank.in and fin.in – in the hope it improves trust in the financial services sector.…

items.title: DeepSeek's iOS app is a security nightmare, and that's before you consider its TikTok links

items.summary:
PLUS: Spanish cops think they've bagged NATO hacker; HPE warns staff of data breach; Lazy Facebook phishing, and more!

Infosec In Brief  DeepSeek’s iOS app is a security nightmare that you should delete ASAP, according to researchers at mobile app infosec platform vendor NowSecure.…

items.title: Huawei revenue growing fast, suggesting China's scoffing at sanctions
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
PLUS: Japan shifts to pre-emptive cyber-defense; Thailand cuts cords connecting scam camps; China to launch 'moon hopper' in 2026; and more!

Asia In Brief  Huawei chair Liang Hua last week told a conference in China that the company expects to meet its revenue targets for 2024, meaning it earned around ¥860 billion ($118.25 billion) – 22 percent growth compared to its 2023 result.…
